title: 111_hr6309
content: The Act may be cited as the "Notification of Origin of Telecommunications and Internet Consumer Exchanges Act of 2010" or the "NOTICE Act of 2010". Definitions are provided in Section 2. The Act defines key terms such as "business entity," "commerce," and "consumer" within the context of conducting commerce in the United States. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of terms related to consumer transactions, including purchases for personal use, customer service communication, telecommunication, and wire communication. The curr_chunk defines wire communication as the transmission of various forms of information through wire, cable, or similar connections. Business entities engaged in customer service communications must disclose their physical location. Business entities must disclose their physical location at the beginning of customer service communications, with exceptions for those located in the United States or when the communication is initiated by a consumer knowingly to a foreign entity. Business entities in the United States are exempt from disclosing their physical location in customer service communications. Exceptions include communications initiated by consumers to foreign entities and emergency service-related communications. Business entities outside the US are exempt from disclosing their physical location in customer service communications. Emergency service communications are also excluded from this requirement. The Federal Trade Commission can exclude certain business entities or communications if exceptionally compelling circumstances justify it. Each year, businesses participating in customer service communications must certify their compliance with the requirements to the FTC. Each year, business entities in customer service communications must certify compliance with the requirements to the Federal Trade Commission. The FTC will promulgate regulations within a year of the Act's enactment to enforce its provisions. The requirements will apply to customer service communications one year after the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT. Any failure to comply with section 3 of the Act will be treated as a violation of FTC regulations on unfair or deceptive acts. The FTC has the power to prevent violations of the Act and impose penalties on violators. The Act incorporates penalties from the Federal Trade Commission Act for violations. The authority of the Federal Trade Commission is not limited by this Act.
